arch:note.arch:string: The purpose of the daily journal was to record the activities taking place in a trench each day. This included which loci were excavated, how and why loci were excavated and the ongoing impressions of the relationships among loci. It should be noted that journals record the actions, impressions and ideas of trench supervisors during the excavations. They are not, therefore, the final interpretations or syntheses of the emerging data.

arch:internalDocument.arch:string:
July 4, 2004   Area E, Trench 2   C. Painter, E. Karaca

Today we began by cutting back the last bit of north baulk from the west section o f the protruding baulk containing L2 on top. As we were doing this Bradley, Diana and Jenny came by and Bradley noted a cream wash with purple band Ubaid rim just below an ash layer visible in this north baulk of the sounding trench. A general view and detailed photograph was taken.

We then proceeded in opening 2 loci in the west expansion area to account for the differentiation in soil colors and textures noted yesterday. L3, whose area was classified yesterday as reddish brown compacted soil, is a light brown (10YR 7/2) compacted clay matrix containing sparsely spread pebbles and rocks <3.0cm in size. In general we believe this is a compacted fill as no clear surface is visible. A small amount of EB pottery sherds (KT1) and lithic flakes (KT2) were uncovered throughout the locus.

Bradley and I had initially thought that a foundation trench, indicated in the west baulk of the sounding by a "u-shaped" piling of large stones, might become apparent when excavating L3, however we were incorrect. Additional excavation below L3 is needed to determine for sure whether a foundation trench is indeed present.

Also from the west baulk of the sounding area we noted the possible gradual sloping of L3 underneath L4, which we opened today and identified from yesterday as white or grayish (10R 7/1) sub-angular soil and in some places almost powdery in texture. We originally thought L4 was only loose fill or perhaps even remaining erosion material as few finds were found, pottery only (KT1) from the NW corner. KT1 is a rim fragment possibly from a chalice vessel.

It became apparent to us that after removing L4, this fill had perhaps been suprasurface fill on top of what appears to be a surface. This surface, L6, is a light brown (7.5YR 7/2) trampled or compacted surface that is a hard clay matrix with sparse small rocks. Upon first examination it seemed that this surface extended north under L3, however with the removal of L3 it is unclear at this time whether L6 is indeed a feature or compacted fill.

Also what we initially thought was a pit cutting into the west central end of L6 turned out to be an animal burrow with another finely preserved compact surface below L6. This new surface’s relationship to L6, whether as superimposed surfaces or L6 acting as suprafill on top, is unclear and will be explored further.

Simultaneously we opened L5, a medium brown compact clay fill with small pebbles and a few scattered stones in the sounding area. No definitive surface feature is discernable at this time. The presence of Ubaid cream wash ware mixed with a few second millennium sherds, as loosely defined in the field by Bradley, l eads us to believe this is a mixed compact fill.

Notably in L5 two types of obsidian blades and flakes are present (KT3) along with a stone burnishing tool (KT4) from the NW corner of the fill, two spindle whorls (KT5 and KT8), a possible third unfinished whorl (KT6) and what is initially being classified as a v-shaped pendant (KT7).

The presence of these activity area objects leads us to believe that an activity or domestic surface or floor may be close below.

CP
